awd_titl_txt: DMREF: Collaborative Research: HybriD3: Discovery, Design, Dissemination of Organic-Inorganic Hybrid Semiconductor Materials for Optoelectronic Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Description: This project, called "HybriD3", aims to accelerate the Design, Discovery, and Dissemination of new crystalline organic-inorganic hybrid semiconductors. The materials to be considered generally consist of a suitable inorganic semiconductor that forms a connected framework, into which targeted organic components integrate. While organic materials have unique attributes, including light weight, mechanical flexibility and possible strong light emission, inorganic systems offer their own unique strengths related to excellent semiconducting and optical characteristics. Notably, while traditional semiconductors (e.g., silicon) are strictly inorganic, organic-inorganic hybrids open up the full arsenal of synthetic organic chemistry for tuning and refining the resulting materials and associated properties. Specifically, the current project targets the paradigm of so-called organic-inorganic (or hybrid) perovskites, aiming to identify new materials opportunities for light-emitting diodes, with better suitability for addressing the important target of energy-efficient lighting and cost-effective manufacturing techniques. However, the materials space to be explored is general, versatile, not yet nearly exhaustively charted, and will likely expose materials with very different, unprecedented and tunable functionality, as the research focuses on understanding previously unexplored interactions between the organic and inorganic hybrid components. A key deliverable for dissemination will be a comprehensive, easily-browsable database of existing, predicted and newly synthesized organic-inorganic hybrids to ensure accelerated development of this materials space among the wider community of researchers now converging around this materials class.

Technical Description: HybriD3 is an integrated, multi-pronged effort, leveraging theory and computation, synthesis, spectroscopy and optoelectronic device prototyping. The activity will create and leverage techniques for more effective computational predictions of organic-inorganic hybrid materials, their carrier properties and excitations, for targeted synthesis and characterization of identified materials prospects. The project will also target proof-of-concept device (primarily light emission) demonstration for the developed hybrid materials. It will thus enable better understanding of key physical processes such as carrier transport, charge/energy transfer between the organic and inorganic sub-components, carrier recombination, and how these properties can be manipulated by refining structure, synthesis and/or deposition of the thin-films or bulk crystals. The planned database will play a long-term role as a go-to resource for an entire community. The PIs will also promote the HybriD3 data for inclusion in broader community databases such as the Materials Project, aflowlib, or the NoMaD Data Repository. Finally, sustainable data dissemination will be ensured by a collaboration with industry leader Springer Materials, to include the HybriD3 data in their product. The PIs also plan to release the HybriD3-developed software and database as open source and build a user community around the project by ensuring that interested researchers are able to contribute to the HybriD3-developed codebase. This will allow a wider growth of the project. This aspect is of special interest to the software cluster in the Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure, which has provided co-funding for this award.

Hybrid Integrated Photonic Integrated Circuits (HIPICs)

Summary

In this ERC, group III-nitrides were supposed to be used an excitation light source to optically pump hybrid perovskites to generate light sources of a wide wavelength range and hybrid perovskites will be integrated to provide light sources over a wide wavelength range across the visible and near-infrared part of the spectrum. Their excellent optical properties along with their solution processability make these materials an excellent candidate to serve as light sources and detector materials.

 

To explore the possibility of using hybrid perovskites as a light source, it is important to evaluate its operating stability. In recent years, there have been a number of reports study the operating stability of perovskite light emitting devices and lasers. We have also carried out the device stability study and have concluded the operating stability of perovskite light source is a very challenging problem and their use for photonics applications will require a major breakthrough in device engineering. The report below describes some of the challenges of perovskite lasers.

 

1. Perovskite lasers

Metal-halide perovskites have recently shown the potential of providing a material platform that enables low-cost lasers covering the whole visible spectrum to be integrated into existing photonic systems, due to their solution-processability, bandgap tunability,1 and low amplified spontaneous emission (ASE) threshold.2 Among various optical resonators reported in the studies on perovskite lasers, distributed feedback (DFB) cavities are of great interest owing to their single-mode operation, low-threshold, and simple structure.

While perovskite DFB lasers have been demonstrated with pulsed optical pumping, their practical applications are still not possible, as continuous wave operation and electrical pumping are extremely challenging to achieve due to the poor stability of perovskite materials.3 To address this crucial issue, one can either improve the stability or reduce the threshold power. Given a laser consisting of a gain medium and an optical resonator, the solutions can be divided into two aspects: one is material engineering aided by structural characterizations and photophysical studies, aiming at enhancing the intrinsic stability of the materials as well as lowering the ASE threshold; while the other is cavity engineering based on optical mode analysis, which reduces the lasing threshold at a device level. 

In this report, we will first present the results from our studies on perovskite DFB lasers, which include photophysical studies and cavity engineering. Then the challenges originated from the stability issue are discussed.

2. Preliminary results

2. Photophysical studies

ASE threshold is a fundamental parameter describing the intrinsic properties of a gain material, and it is determined by the excited charge carrier dynamics as well as different recombination pathways. To achieve a low ASE threshold, non-radiative recombination pathways, typically defect-assisted recombination, should be suppressed. Due to the crystalline nature and robust solution-process of perovskites, grain boundaries are a major source of defects. Therefore, to reduce the ASE threshold, we added a polymer polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) as a passivation agent into a perovskite (MAPbBr3) to passivate the grain boundary defects. The resulting films with and without PVP were subjected to ASE measurements. As we can see, the film without PVP does not show ASE even at a high pumping fluence of 185 mJ/cm2, while the film with PVP shows ASE at a pumping fluence of 37 mJ/cm2.

3. Stability issue

Perovskite materials can undergo severe degradation due to many factors such as moisture, photoexcitation, and electric field. To have a better understanding, here, we distinguish the issue into three categories: (i) environmental stability associated with chemical species (e.g., water) in the atmosphere; (ii) photostability; and (iii) electrical stability. The environmental stability should not be a real problem, as encapsulation techniques are mature enough to suppress the interaction of perovskites with the atmosphere to a negligible level. In contrast, the photostability and electrical stability are the critical factors that not only are responsible for the operational lifetime of various perovskite-based devices but also determine the possibility of continuous wave operation and electrical pumping of perovskite lasers.

4. Summary

 In summary, we demonstrated some preliminary results showing our efforts to reduce the threshold of perovskite lasers through both material engineering and cavity engineering. However, due to the extremely poor stability of perovskites under photoexcitation and electrical field, it is extremely challenging at the current stage to achieve stable continuous wave operation or electrical pumping at room temperature. Therefore, before we devote more efforts to use perovskite lasers for integrated photonic circuits, the stability issue of this type of materials must be addressed for the sake of providing the possibilities of fulfilling their practical applications.
